overview.short: Trueperella are Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, non-motile pleomorphic rods (often coryneform) that are facultative anaerobes and can be associated with pyogenic infections in animals and occasionally humans.
overview.clinical_context: Most clinically relevant isolates are opportunistic and may be recovered from wound infections, abscesses, and mixed polymicrobial infections.

field_notes.Shape: Trueperella are classically pleomorphic/coryneform rods; your schema collapses this to Rods.
field_notes.Haemolysis: Haemolysis is species-dependent and may be variable at genus level.
field_notes.Catalase: Often catalase-negative, helping separate from many coryneform genera that are catalase-positive.

key_differentiators.notes: Many Corynebacterium are catalase-positive, whereas Trueperella is typically catalase-negative.
Helps separate from small Gram-variable/Gram-negative appearing organisms that may overlap clinically.
Cutibacterium is typically anaerobic; Trueperella commonly grows under both aerobic and anaerobic conditions.

common_confusions.reason: Both can appear as pleomorphic Gram-positive rods; biochemical overlap requires confirmatory identification.
Historical overlap and clinical context can confuse; some labs may still use older naming conventions.

when_to_question_identification: Strong catalase positivity suggests Corynebacterium rather than Trueperella.
Strict anaerobic-only growth suggests Cutibacterium or other anaerobes.
Classic Gram-positive cocci morphology suggests Streptococcus/Staphylococcus rather than Trueperella.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Quick screen to separate from catalase-positive coryneform organisms.
Best practical confirmatory method for genus/species resolution in routine labs.
Definitive identification when MALDI confidence is low or for unusual isolates.
